reviewText: This was worse than a high school video production. Nothing more than a long commercial/marketing tool for the realtor that produced/stars/wrote this piece of garbage. From the poor editing, content, lack of historical facts, poor questioning, lack of depth, and so on... I was really looking forward to viewing this, as an Eichler owner, and a fan of Mid-Century Modern architecture.  So disappointing. Don't be tricked, this is not a documentary. I feel bad for some of the people interviewed, they were conned into making a commercial without being paid.

The film talked about Eichler and why people were -- and still are --  attracted to these homes.  There were also  numerous photographs and glimpses inside the homes during the interviews.  If you expect to see an on-screen tour of homes, you may be disappointed; however, this film offers so much more to enthusiasts.

It always breaks my heart when people choose to profane God's name when He is the very one who has given us life - and even more importantly - His beloved Son, Jesus ...

"In this is love: not that we have loved God, but that He loved us and sent His Son to be the atoning sacrifice for our sins."
1 John 4:10

"You shall not take the name of The LORD your God in vain, for The LORD will not hold guiltless anyone who takes His name in vain."
Exodus 20:7

"Now repent of your sins and turn to God, so that your sins may be wiped away."
Acts 3:19

Warning! Don't waste your $2.00 on this video. It's just what the title says: the people, not the houses. It was so boring that I could not stand listening to the monotone of the people and stop watching. Even deleted it from my video library. I would not even give it a star.
Eichler was a genius in his ability to design and build beautiful homes for middle class families. This book explains how and why.

One day, I'd love to own an Eichler. Growing up in Southern California in the '50s and '60s, I look at everything midcentury modern with fondness, but nothing beats this architect's vision and execution of the most unique and affordable (at the time!) homes. This documentary tells the story of Eichler himself (surprising), several homeowners ( endearing) and the interviews with his son and grandson really took it over the top for me. Anyone fortunate enough to own one of these homes, or just has an interest in midcentury architecture, should love it.
